strIntroduction: Join us to see the real OKINAWA on our cycling tour! Feel closer to the city to ride a bike in Okinawa, cycling along the beautiful coast with sea breeze. It will be something different. Every year, "Tour de Okinawa" has been held on Okinawa beautiful coastline. In this activity, we will explore the city of Okinawa road bike along with the local people. You can also take a bike ride the same course as "Tour de Okinawa" in the options. Please enjoy to cycling with rich nature of Okinawa.
strTitle: Cycling Okinawa

strIntroduction: A large international market as the main street of Okinawa, There is a public market. In this market is lined with a lot of unique ingredients of Okinawa and various types of fishmonger and seafood caught in the sea of Okinawa. In the second floor there is also a dining room using with ingredients on the market, you can enjoy fresh and delicious Okinawa dishes. After your experience, the charm of living in the local public market that I can not tell is the only guide book, in this experience is to eat lunch together in the dining room on the second floor. Try to fully enjoy the fun of food markets in Okinawa. Don't miss this special experience!
strTitle: Experience the Food Culture in the Public Market of Okinawa!

strIntroduction: Join us for lunch in the resort paradise of Okinawa. We're young, local college students eager to meet new people and have a fun time! I'm a university student who really likes to walk around find new places to eat, whether that's in a restaurant or street food. As part of this experience, we'll eat at Ryukyu University, which houses the largest cafeteria in Okinawa. Lunch is quite cheap here and there's a lot of variety. I'll introduce you to Okinawan dishes such as goya champuru and Okinawa soba, or if you prefer to stick with regular Japanese food, Japanese curry or ramen is also available. So why not have lunch with me? I'll share my knowledge of Okinawa's local history with you and we'll also chat up other students. It'll be a great experience to meet me, other locals and taste good Japanese food.
strTitle: Let's have lunch at the University of the Ryukyus
Go Shopping at Okinawa Kokusai Street with a Local Student!

strIntroduction: I am a professional tour guide and also a housewife living in Kyoto for 2 decades. I have had the opportunity to invite many foreign friends at home and every guest I had seemed to enjoy cooking Japanese traditional dishes with me. I will teach you how to make healthy and delicious dish with you and I will provide some tips and ideas for those who live abroad. In this activity, you will be invited to my house to enjoy a cooking session together. And you will also eat the dishes you cook. (The menu will be changed according to season, as the vegetables and fish will change.) As a professional guide, I will give precise instruction on how to cook yourself and also plenty of background knowledge as well! (Service disponible sur demande en français, au niveau intermediate)
strTitle: Home Cooking in My House
10/31 Let's Go to a Japanese "Visual-kei" Concert!

strIntroduction: Do you know what " Takoyaki" is? - Takoyaki is a small ball- shaped Japanese snack filled with diced octopus. Have you ever tried it and are interested in making it by yourself ? - "Takoyaki making" is really easy and quite of fun. All you have to do is to rotate and turn the Takoyaki upside down on a special Takoyaki-pan! I would love to give you a special tip to make them adorable :) In this activity, you can … - enjoy Takoyaki-making at home in my share house - have fun tasting your own Takoyaki - chat with us Tokyo University students about life in Tokyo :) I would be very happy to welcome you and introduce "Takoyaki-experience" to you!!
strTitle: Takoyaki Making with Tokyo University Students!
Fancy Cafe-Bar experience -Tim Burton's favorite-

strIntroduction: Gyoza are delicious Chinese dumplings quite popular in Japan. Every home has a different way of making it, and Gyoza comes in different flavours from one house to another I like cooking and often hold home parties with my friends, and make Gyoza for them. In this activity, you will learn how to cook Gyoza and we will eat it together. You will be able to host Gyoza parties with your friends and family back in your home country, so join me to take a piece of Japan back home! (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/adactio/42099674/)
strTitle: Cook Fried Dumplings with a Local Chef in Tokyo

strIntroduction: In this activity we'll take you from the meeting place to our house, and make and eat "Gyouza" (Fried dumplings) together. I hope to show you how to make the "gyouza" we often eat at home. "Gyoza" is a Chinese dish, but is often on the tables of Japanese homes yet the taste of the "gyouza" varies between homes. We, the Hatano family, consist of my husband, myself and two cats living in a small apartment that has a quaint garden. If you come to our house, you'll see what a young family in Japan is like. I'll also print out and give you our homemade secret recipe for "gyoza" that's been passed on from my parents after the activity. On request, we can also go get ingredients for the "Gyoza" at a local supermarket together before the activity starts . At our house, you can also see what types of food are in a typical Japanese family's home. Through explaining all the food and ingredients at our house and at a supermarket, I hope to show you, again, what a Japanese family is like.
strTitle: Learn to Cook Fried Dumplings, a Food Culture in Japan
Let's Go to a Japanese "Visual-kei" Concert!

strIntroduction: Fun Tour Duration: 10:00 am – 6:00 pm KAWAGOE This place is filled with nostalgic remnants that resembles Kyoto, so for people visiting Tokyo and could not visit Kyoto, this is the most recommended sight to go to experience traditional Japan outside Tokyo. Activities in Kawagoe (Little Old Edo Town) ☆ Meet the mythical friendly fox of Kawagoe, "Priya" and get served Japanese food while being with the friendly animal ☆ Visit a few temples along the way, picture taking in front of "The Bell of Time" - Toki no Kane ☆ Try out Japanese candies from confectionery stores and buy Japanese omiyage ☆ Explore architecture and the back streets of old houses OMIYA Omiya is one of the busiest wards in Saitama prefecture. In my opinion, this is one of the most underrated shopping spots that is just a couple of train stations away from Tokyo. Activities in Omiya ☆ Visit Omiya and check out ARCHE, a popular mall ☆ Purikura Session and Check Lumine ☆ Visit Omiya Shrine and Park ☆ Visit Loft and Bic Camera for shopping *If time permits, we can drop by at the Railway Museum first.
strTitle: Kawagoe Old Edo Tour + Omiya

strIntroduction: When visiting Japan, I highly recommend visiting any theme park. Be it Tokyo Disneyland, Disneysea, Namja Town in Ikebukuro.... I am sure that it will be one of your favorite days in your trip! I have been to Disyneland and Disneysea for many times and I will show and teach you how to maximize your money, just like the frequent Japanese goers. Dressing up like Minnie, Daisy, Alice, whoever your favorite Disney character is-- I'm all in! Aside from Disney theme parks, you can even choose to go to any of the following below too: ☆ Fuji Q Highland - This crazy theme park is known for terrible roller coasters and rides and will literally blow your hair away with excitement. One of the best in the world, I would say. ☆ Sanrio Puroland: If you are truly a Hello Kitty or Sanrio fan, a Gift Gate shop is just not enough for you.. you must visit Puroland and dressed up in kawaii glory! Eat your favorite lunch placed in a cute My Melody bento box and cry out of joy when you see rows and rows of different Sanrio character souvenirs that cannot be found elsewhere. ☆ Ghibli Museum: Get a chance to witness how Ghibli creators have dedicated their lives in producing Japan's own pride and contribution to the world-- Animation. Meet Totoro, take a ride on the "neko" bus and have an incredible time looking at the real materials used in producing these artsy films. (please take note that photography and videos are not allowed inside the museum itself.)
strTitle: Kawaii Dress-up Day in any Theme Park of your choice

strIntroduction: Fun Tour Duration: 10:00 am – 6:00 pm Ginza is known to be the upscale area of Tokyo. This place offers many luxury brands from the west (Chanel, Dior, Abercrombie & Fitch, Gucci, Louis Vuitton), and many buildings are European-styled. Just recently, UNIQLO has opened their biggest flagship store (12 floors!) in Ginza. Activities in Ginza (Tokyo's Poshest Place) ☆ Walk around for some shopping & picture-taking ☆ Go to Ginza Wako, an iconic building ☆ Have a quick visit at SONY and Apple Store ☆ Take a break and meet Peko-chan @ Fujiya Restaurant and eat some cakes! ☆ Shop at Japan's favorite store- UNIQLO (If time permits, we can visit the Police Museum which is for free admission.) ODAIBA Odaiba is a large artificial island in Tokyo Bay where you can see the beautiful rainbow bridge at night. This place is a popular sightseeing and shopping destination for tourists and the Japanese themselves. There are so many major attractions that can keep your day full! You will never run out of things to do in Odaiba. Ride the Yurikamome line and have a satisfying visual tour of the amazing man-made island! Activities in Odaiba ☆ Check out Tokyo Big Sight Area for conventions ☆ Go to Palette Town (Car Show) / Daikanransha (Ferris Wheel) and Venus Fort ☆ Eat pancakes and take Purikura at Hello Kitty’s Kawaii Paradise ☆ Visit Venus Fort Shopping Place, Diver’s City and Gundam Statue Picture Taking ☆ Walk towards Decks Odaiba (Trick Art Museum, Showa Retro & Exile Food Court) & Visit Fuji TV head office ☆ Move to Statue of Liberty for late afternoon viewing of the Tokyo Bay (If time permits, we can still try to shop at Aqua City.)
strTitle: Ginza Walk / Shopping & Odaiba Bay Area Day Tours

strIntroduction: Fun Tour Duration: 10:00 am – 6:00 pm Nippori, famously known as the Textile or Fabric Town, is definitely one of the favorite places of Fashion students in Tokyo! You can get Japanese-style garments and the cutest materials for your own craft ideas. This is where I get my own resources for my crazy-themed outfits and Kawaii DIY projects (www.kawaii-diy.com). Nippori is a small town but with so many offerings and I am sure you will enjoy your fabric shopping spree there. After our morning shopping, I will invite you to my humble abode as we have our own creative sessions with our materials. Prior to that, we have many things we can also do in my homely neighborhood. ^^v Activities for Nippori & Kita Urawa tour: ☆ Using the Yamanote Line, we go to Nippori. We can have our brunch there as well. ☆ Introduce "POP GIRL", a shop that offers inexpensive yet stylish Japanese street fashion! ☆ After Nippori, we will go to Kita Urawa, Saitama! We can have sushi or buy cooked bento for a snack in my place. ☆ Visit 100 yen shop at Kita Urawa Station or Urawa Parco Yuzawaya (lots of DIY stuff here) ☆ Let’s make cute bows & lolita-inspired pieces from yours truly, Kawaii DIY sensei ^^ ☆ Have a small in-door picnic / rainbow party @ my rainbowholic place ☆ Play dress-up and take photos together~
strTitle: Nippori Fabric Town Visit + Kawaii DIY Session

strIntroduction: Fun Day Tour: 10:00 am – 6:00 pm Whenever I want to shop but I don't want to burn a hole in my pockets, Ueno is always my savior. I can still remember the first time I visited this holy land of pandas and cheap fashion items.. I had such a great time! Now that I am a frequent shopper here, I know where I can bring you so that you will have a fun shopping experience without sacrificing most of your bucks. Along with that, we will be able to enjoy everything in Panda form (Panda bread, Panda bag, Panda-shaped chocolates, etc.). UENO ☆ Shop at Ameyokocho for cheap & outlet price of brands ☆ Shoeholic Haul!! Visit Mita Sneakers and Doc Martens Outlet Shop ☆ Try out some cakes & sweets in Panda form/katachi ☆ Eat the BEST Kebab in Ueno!! ☆ Walk around Ueno ☆ Take a ride on the monorail ☆ Have a rest in the beautiful Ueno Park ☆ Visit OLD Japan museum Akihabara, also known as Tokyo's Electric Town, is a mecca for all Anime fans. Maid cafes, gachapon / toy capsules, special hobby stores, Akiba idol theaters, mangas ... these are only a few that this amazing and jaw-dropping place can offer to every tourist. Akihabara, for me, is a perfect image of Japan and Technology. AKIHABARA ☆ Visit Yodobashi Camera (electronics, hobby games, etc.) ☆ Have Gundam waffles from Gundam cafe ☆ Tour around Akihabara and Maid Cafes or Hobby Shops ☆ Visit unique shops & immerse in the anime coolture of Japan

strIntroduction: Fun Tour Duration: 10:00 am – 6:00 pm Shinjuku is one of the fast-paced areas in Tokyo. It's a business district with lots of shopping offerings for tourists. After attending a language school in Shinjuku for a year, you can tell that I've become familiar with the area already. Just one station away from Shinjuku, we can also take a quick visit at Shin-Okubo, the "Korean Town" in Tokyo. SHINJUKU ☆ Shinjuku Marui One (lolita / gothic / kawaii fashion) ☆ Lumine / My World ☆ Closet Child (Lolita Resale Shop) and Visual Kei Indie Records Shop ☆ BIC CAMERA ☆ Visit Metropolitan Tower Observatory ☆ Pass by Mode Gakuen If time permits: ☆ Go around Shinjuku Kabuki-cho and check out the Cabaret and Hosto Town (in daylight). ☆ We can also insert a short Shin-okubo (Korea town) tour. Shibuya is known to have dozens of fashion shopping malls & Japanese fashion brands. This is also where the famous story of Hachiko happened. SHIBUYA ☆ Shibuya Crossing / Shibuya Scramble ☆ Meet Hachiko (from the popular movie that brought many into tears) ☆ Shop at the famous SHIBUYA 109 that houses kawaii & gal fashion ☆ Quick visit at Loft / Village Vanguard / BOOK OFF / DISNEY STORE Shibuya ☆ Purikura sessions in SEGA (as schoolgirls, maido-san, etcetera) ぜひ最先端の"Kawaii Fashion"を楽しんでみてください！
strTitle: Shinjuku & Shibuya SHOPPING Day Tour
Harajuku & Shibuya SHOPPING Day Tour

strIntroduction: We will start at Mitsukoshimae, home of the Bank of Japan and the outfit which bills itself as the "world's oldest department store" Mitsukoshi, replete with iconic Lions et al. We then take the short journey to Akasaka-Mitsuke, home of the tranquil bliss that is Hie Shrine and the equally tranquil Hotel New Otani gardens. An opportunity to sample the traditional Japanese sweet an-mitsu and macha tea will be available inside an iconic New Otani bar, should guests wish. We then proceed to the shopping delights of Omotesando, working our way up the shrine approach until reaching the fabulous Meiji Shrine. We then proceed to Ame-yoko-cho for bargain hunting, before finishing up in marvelous souvenir paradise Asakusa and great views of the tallest building in Japan, the Sky Tree.
strTitle: Delights of the Ginza Line Tour

strIntroduction: We begin fairly early in the morning with a visit to a sumo training stable, where we witness a living link to the samurai age, and some of Japan's strongest men up close. We then tie this in with historic and quirky sumo monuments and sights nearby, and I even offer restaurant recommendations for lunch or future visits. As a leading sumo writer with an expert knowledge of Tokyo's streets, we can really combine a lot of fun things here. Sumo training is mainly held in Tokyo at these times: January 3rd-22nd February 2nd-20th April 15th-May 21st June 2nd-21st August 20th-Sept 21st Oct 2nd-25th Dec 10th-20th Training is finished by 10am, so reservations must be at 7am.
strTitle: Sumo Training and Culture, Hidden Gems of Tokyo

strIntroduction: Have you heard of MIRACLE PAINT? It’s used for face painting, but the paint is different from usual face paint. To wash off the face paint, it normally involves lots and lots of water. HOWEVER With MIRACLE PAINT, there’s no need to use water- you can peel off the paint! The reason is that it’s made from rubber! In this activity, we will teach you: - how to paint with MIRACLE PAINT - how to paint Japanese style pictures - how to draw on friends’ faces etc... Come and join the fun with us and learn how to face paint!
strTitle: Learn Japanese Face Painting with Miracle Paint

strIntroduction: Tokyo is a relatively new city - coming into being in 1868. Its predecessor, Edo, on the other hand was around for several hundred years before the Meiji Restoration of 1867. Remnants few and far between remain, but on this walking tour with local guide and long-time editor and writer on Japanese culture, Mark Buckton, that history will be brought to life in the Asakusa and Ueno areas around Senso-ji, Ueno Park, Ameyoko-cho, and a few places not listed on many maps - before we venture down to the always buzzing world famous Akihabara Electric Town district - home of the latest and greatest in Japanese electronics, maid cafes, and more neon than can be found in most other cities nationwide.
strTitle: Tokyo Then and Now - The Past Meets the Present

strIntroduction: Kabuki is arguably the most famous form of theatre born of the Japanese islands and time spent at any show will open a side of the culture most will miss. From serious plays to the more humorous of performances, romance, histories and tragedies, kabuki has it all and then some. Painted faces, exaggerated gestures, wonderful sets and actors whose whose names have been used for centuries make up a day / show at the kabuki. Performances can be enjoyed for as little as 45 minutes to 3 or 4 hours - and all in the company of a person who has worked closely with the people running kabuki on tours to the US, England, and France. *Activity cost does NOT include the price for the Kabuki tickets
strTitle: Kabuki - Japan's Most High Profile Theatre Form

strIntroduction: Tsukiji fish market is the largest such facility in the world. Daily, thousands of tons of sea creatures large and small are landed and pass through Tsukiji on their way to many of Tokyo's 60,000 restaurants and further afield all over Japan. As a guide, I have taken individuals and small groups around the bustling inner market for over 10 years to view all the action and stalls up close and in person. We will see sales agreed, fishmongers by the dozen preparing their fish, live and dead, for sale and so much more. Oftentimes we then relax over a breakfast of sushi in the outer market which sells veggies, kitchen goods, prepared foods and even stuffed animals! This tour can come with or without the sushi option for breakfast so let us know what you want and we will see what we can do.
strTitle: Tsukiji Morning Madness!

strIntroduction: This is an activity where you will learn a traditional type of dance in Japan is “buyo”. Using the techniques of “Noo” and “Kabuki” as a base, we have shaped the activity so that the layperson can dance “buyo” on stage or anywhere else. You can experience “Fujima style buyo” – one of the largest schools of “buyo” that is characterized by its powerful and large gestures. You will… • Practice how to sit or stand when in a Kimono or in a Japanese room. • Learn how to dance a simple “Geisha” or “Samurai” performance (If requested) Because lessons can be taken in English or Chinese, we have people participating from around the world. It is my wish that as many visitors as possible experience traditional Japanese entertainment. Come and participate casually! Tell us beforehand, if you have any other particular dances you’d like to learn.
strTitle: Learn How to Perform a Traditional Japanese Dance

strIntroduction: This is NOT your standard tour company exposure aimed at profit making with wrestlers putting on a show. This is the real deal. I have been a sumo writer for 10 years, and a guide for around 7 years at morning practice and real tournaments. I have taken people from around the world, from Hollywood stars and global business leaders to sports stars and regular guys in regular jobs. In this activity, I'll take you to a sumo stable near JR Ryogoku Station early in the morning.
strTitle: Guided Tour of Sumo Morning Practice

strIntroduction: With this plan, you’ll be able to experience traditional “shugyou”(training) through “Zazen”. You can learn the heart of Zen! Even Steve Jobs is said to have been a practitioner of “zazen” for inspiration. That iPod you’re using right now just might be the result of “Zazen“! You might ask, though…”Aren’t there many ways to practice Zazen?” The answer is yes, each faction of Buddhism requires different styles and methods, but the philosophy behind all “Zazen” is the same. The goal is to face all of your problems, your aspirations and your desires through meditation – to truly be honest with yourself. The basics of “Zazen” are rather simple. First, take a deep breath using your stomach instead of your chest – relax. Then, sit cross-legged, cross your arms, and close your eyes. With this, both body and mind will be in peace. For those who think they might have a difficult time sitting cross-legged, there is an easier way that will be taught, so beginners are very welcome! Plan Schedule: - A walk through a traditional Japanese garden - “Zazen experience” - Drink Japanese green tea and eat teacakes - (Buddhist vegetarian lunch optional) The walk will be held at “Saishouji”, a large Zen Buddhist Temple near Kagurazaka in Tokyo. It’s a historic temple built originally by Shogun Tokugawa Iemitsu, 370 years ago during the Edo period. Book this plan now and experience the very heart of Zen Buddhism – the very heart of Japan.
strTitle: Experience the Spirit of Zen Through Meditation

strIntroduction: The first man in Japan to bake bread is said to be Egawa Hidetatsu in the early 1800s. Today, bread in Japan is very common – and very popular. There are so many types of bread, in fact, that it’s unbelievable. Step into any local convenience store and you’ll find 20 different types of bread to choose from. Step into a bread store, and you’ll have too many to choose from. In this activity, we’ll show you how to bake Japanese-style bread! You’ll get to mix-in ingredients you never thought would go well with bread – such as the anpan (bean paste-filled bread with sesame on top). We’ll choose the best dough for bread you would like to bake! 1) Explanation of the recipe for the bread we’ll be baking 2) Make dough together 3) Leaven dough together 4) Start Baking 5) Wait until bread is fully baked 6) Eat the bread you made while having tea. 7) Take home any leftovers! Let us explain our services as following. - 1. Visiting Japanese home I live in Tokyo city area as a newly-married couple. We provide the cooking class not at the cooking studio but at our home. Please come to our home and fell the Japanese home. My husband's hobby is Kendo. It is Japanese traditional martial arts which Samurais practiced very much to be stronger in the past. If you want , you can experience this Samurai's martial arts. - 2. The lessons of how to cook the Japanese dishes and eating I prepare the beautiful and delicious Japanese traditional menu which varies seasonally. Using seasonable ingredients helps not only to maintain bodily functions, but also to feel four seasons. Japanese food have developed in a unique way, and you can experience that originality by making them. If you want, I can customize the menu. Please ask me what ever you want to cook and eat. - 3. Thorough explanations in English I have the experience of study and work in California USA, and I'm working for the international school as a school nurse now. - 4. Special gifts When we make the Sushi at the class, we use the Sushi roll kit which you can get for free. It is so simple and easy that you can cook again after going back to your county. Additionally I prepared the Tenugui for you to feel the Japanese mind. However I will be on maternity leave from December 2014, so please contact me for future availability. Thank you!
strTitle: Learn Japanese Baking and Cooking in a Japanese Home

strIntroduction: This is a good opportunity to think about your mind and body from the inside out through zen meditation. You can experience Japanese traditional meditation (Zen). You will concentrate on your mind and relax. Close your eyes and relax and have a conversation with yourself. I will teach you how to meditate and the meaning of sutra. -Program: 16:30: Meeting point Kourakuen station (Metro Marunochi-line,Nanboku-line) 16:50: Introduction to the Temple 17:00: Zazen Meditation(2 hours) 19:30: Great dinner at the best local restaurant (2,500yen doesn't include lunch. Lunch depends on you want to eat)

strIntroduction: It will be a good opportunity to think about your mind and body from the inside out through zen meditation and Pilates. Pilates will make your heart free from stress while building a beautiful body. You can experience this strict Japanese traditional meditation. Careful because this is a bit hardcore. The monk may hit you with a Buddhist stick – if you want. ■Highlights: Zazen Shodo Tea Ceremony ■Program: 9:00: Meeting Place: Higashi-Nakano station (JR/Toei-Line) 9:30: Introduction to the Temple 10:00: Zazen Meditation, SHODO (Japanese Calligraphy), Japanese tea ceremony 13:30: Great lunch at the best local restaurant (3,000yen doesn't include lunch. Lunch is around 1,000yen)

strIntroduction: Stone decoration is a hot trend in Japan. How do you feel about experiencing this trend by learning the decoration’s styles and methods? Together, we can decorate your phone (maybe an iPhone?) and make it one of a kind! There are two courses for this activity - one that is an hour long and another for two hours. The basic schedule for each of the course will be as follows: 1) Learn how to efficiently use quick-dry glue. 2) Practice gluing stones. 3) Start your design (you will copy an already-made design if you choose to do the one hour course) by actually gluing the stones onto a sticker. 4) When the glue is dry, your finished! - With the two hour course, you can do all of the above plus choose your own design while using a wide of range of colors for your stones. After the course, you will have finished making stone decoration stickers you can now, of course, stick onto anything you like! Do it and make your friends jealous! Stone decoration stickers decorated to look like your initials make a great present as well! (2hr course only)
strTitle: Learn How to Decorate with Swarovski Rhinestones!

strIntroduction: Takigyo, also called waterfall meditation, consists of standing underneath a waterfall - often strongly rapid - for a prolonged period of time wearing a uniform that is traditional to Buddhism. The purpose of this all isn't to feel pleasure in the pain of the surging water, of course, but to clear your mind of all thought - a core teaching in Buddhism. It's cold, but worth it. This waterfall is nestled in the depths of Takaosan (a mountain in Hachiougi), and is fairly easy to get to. It's an hour train ride away from JR Shinjuku station and then a 15min cable car ride to the waterfall. The ride - especially the cable car ride - provides magnificent views of Japan, and is as worthwhile as the Takigyo itself. So, enjoy the view, experience the training, and then take a soothing bath in one of the natural springs Takaosan provides. (Fee includes ascetic training fee.)
strTitle: Experience Japanese Ascetic Training: Waterfall Meditation

strIntroduction: "Nagashi-suki" is almost unexplainable in words, making "Washi"-making a must-see, and a must-do. Washi (traditional Japanese paper) has been used in Japan since the year 610 and its usage extends from paper for pillows to paper for poetry ("tanzaku"). "Washi" is also fairly expensive, but it's price is due to its fine quality. It is delicately manufactured from very thin fiber, so the end-product is paper that is slim but durable. This process of manufacturing from thin fiber is called "Nagashi-suki" - something that is incredibly interesting to see and best seen at a traditional washi-making company like Ozuwashi in Tokyo. Ozuwashi will not only let you see the process, but will let you make "washi" from scratch! When your done, you keep the washi you made! Find out and experience what "Nagashi-suki"/"washi"-making is at Ozuwashi! Book it now! (Fee Includes "washi" making fee.) (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/clothfairy/3353650877/)
strTitle: Make "Washi" !

strIntroduction: Takoyaki is a dish and it comes from Osaka originally. Takoyaki's main ingredients are octopus, flower and water. It is ball-shaped and we normally eat with special source for it. Its size is around 5cm in diameter and cook with special equipment for making ball-shaped. With this activity, we will make the 100 Takoyakis at Japanese people's house together and eat them! Please make yourself at home like real Japanese and enjoy our speciality. (Including foods and drink.) (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/superwebdeveloper/4068201584/) (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/stephen-oung/6081982324/)
strTitle: Cook and Eat 100 Takoyakis

strIntroduction: Okonomiyaki (Japanese pizza) is a dish and there are several kinds of Okonomiyaki, but mainly when we say Okonomiyaki it is from Kansai region or Hiroshima. Main ingredients are flour, water, vegetables, meats and sea-foods. It is round-shaped and we normally eat with special source for it. For cooking this, we use an special equipment called 'Teppan', it is like a big barbecue pan. With this activity, we will make Okonomiyaki at shop together and eat them! You can choose any ingredients to mix Okonomiyaki, so let us innovate a new Okonomiyaki. (Including foods and drink.) (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/mshades/2603621801/) (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/sskennel/1338333688/) (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/wurzle/19109470/)
strTitle: Cook and Eat Japanese Pizza: Okonomiyaki

strIntroduction: Shopping and taking a walk in Harajuku like Japanese Visual-kei people! This activity teaches you where to buy things for Visual-kei such as clothes, shoes or goods for make-up and also how to become Visual-kei people. We offer you the real Visual-kei experience who knows really well about it. Do not hesitate to ask any questions about Visual-kei! (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/miriamparkinson/5387453820/)
strTitle: Buy Visual-kei Fashion Clothes in Harajuku

strIntroduction: Have you ever decorated your cell phone? Teenagers and “gyaru’s”* love making their cell phones look cuter with decoration. The decorated phones are called "Deco-den" – an acronym for the words Decorated Denwa (Telephone). Using shiny beads, plastic flowers and other charming goodies, the decoration artist will make your cell phone the cutest and most original in the world. Find out why “gyarus” adore “deco-den”! You can decorate any of your other personal belongings you bring to the activity as well! * “Gyaru” http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gyaru (Decoration fee is not included)
strTitle: Decorate Your Mobile: J-POP Style
Experience Japanese Digital Design in a Cutting Edge Venue

strIntroduction: This activity consists of seeing the Tokyo cityscape with a Mountain Bike. In Tokyo, there’s so many areas suited for a nice ride bike; for example there’s Jiyugaoka Harajuku, and Asakusa - all these places are better seen on a bike because the roads are flat and there are so many small things missed if not on one. With this activity, I’ll show you around Tokyo on a mountain bike! You don’t need to bring your own bike but if you would like to, then please do. We also have another spare bike, so invite your friends! (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/mujitra/4757781100/ sizes/z/in/photostream/)
strTitle: Mountain Bike Ride in Tokyo

strIntroduction: Jogging is popular in Japan, especially around the Imperial Palace. The course is lush with nature while being flat without any steep slopes so the run is smooth. When you’re done with the run, you will be absorbed in an overwhelming feeling of satisfaction and tranquility. In this activity you will… • Jog around the Imperial Palace in Tokyo with a passionate jogger Let’s take a jog together and feel the “dignified” atmosphere of the Imperial palace and make new friends! (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/lululemonathletica/4314770350/) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/ando_yo/120925787/) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/yiie/4860159755/)
strTitle: Take a Jog Around the Imperial Palace

strIntroduction: Japanese food has become popular all over the world, but still sushi or noodles dominate the menus of most overseas Japanese restaurants making it very difficult for most to imagine what an average Japanese person eats. Imagine your own comfort foods back home. There is nothing especially fancy about a normal Japanese family’s home-cooked meal but that is what makes it special. Take this opportunity to learn about real Japanese food with real Japanese families, an experience that cannot be met by a visit to any great local restaurant. Not only will you be able to explore new dishes during these meals, this will be a fantastic opportunity to have a meaningful cultural exchange or practice your Japanese skills. Think of it as a short home-stay program for those who do not have the time but still want the experience. There are families that welcome visitors during the day at lunch too so check through your schedule to see if you can find some time for a nice Home Visit. The Hayashi family will serve a Japanese home-cooking staple, pork cutlets among other dishes. In the meal they will also have sauteed pork, braised beef and potatoes, miso-soup, homemade sushi, just so you can try and expand your palate. 1. Meet host family at nearby landmark 2. Go to home to relax and enjoy lunch or dinner 3. Say goodbyes to family and leave home You can really feel the old town atmosphere seeing Toden streetcars.
strTitle: Join the Hayashi family for a real Japanese meal at home

strIntroduction: Japan's Otaku (geek) culture is booming. In the past, the geek culture in Japan was rather looked down upon by the mainstream as too geekish, but now with vast media coverage the "otaku" culture has become somewhat of a subculture and something fashionable. In particular, the Maid Cafe has been rising in popularity. With the soaring popularity of the word "moe" in Japan, which means something like "cute", the maid cafe has also gained rapid growth. These cafes are unique in that all customers are served by female workers who wear maid outfits usually designed to look like the ones seen on popular Japanese animations. What is more unique about the cafe, though, is that these maids will play various types of card games, board games and video games with you as you dine or simply talk with one of these adorable girls. Oh, and they will call you "goshujinsama" which means "master"! Trust me, it's pretty sweet. With this plan, we will go to an actual Cafe in Akihabara and order a drink while we talk to the maids. Maybe even play games or take pictures with the maids if you really feel up to it! Book it now for an experience you will never forget! (Includes one drink)
strTitle: Visit a Maid Cafe in Akihabara

strIntroduction: Thoroughly enjoy Akihabara with this activity!! In this activity you will go to an, 'Cat Cafe'', and a Maid Cafe' 'Ear Cleaning shop' with me. ---------- "Cat Cafe" This is where you can play and spend a relaxing time with cats. It's quite a new and popular spot in Japan. The greatest feature is that there are lots of lovely cats that you can touch and hold them. You will feel them close and warm. In this plan, you can play with cats for an hour. We will go to the "Cat Cafe" with you and provide language support. (Not Includes entrance fee, Drink and foods) ---------- "Maid Cafe" This is a Cafe where the waiters are maids in very cute costumes At the Maid Cafe, other than having a drink (juice, coffee, or alcohol) or eating, you can also take photos and play simple/fun games with the Maids. You will go to a Maid Cafe with me and enjoy one complementary drink I will help you enjoy your time by providing language support as well! (Not Includes entrance fee) ** You might wait a long line for one hour to enter the shop. Because it is very popular. During the hour, we will explain a lot about Japan. ---------- "Ear Cleaning Shop" This is a place where staff members wearing Yukata (traditional Japanese clothes) clean your ears gently at a Japanese-style room for 30 min. This is definitely a rare experience! You usually clean your ears by yourself right? Once you experience this, you'll never want to clean your own ears again. If you like it, you can experience this. ---------- Let me coordinate and support your Akihabara experience!
strTitle: Akihabara Deep Otaku Package

strIntroduction: JHI provides a wealth of information regarding navigating the Japanese medical system. We make necessary arrangements for clients so that they can receive optimal medical care while in Japan. Clients covered are provided with individual assistance to locate English-speaking doctors/other medical services and make appointments. The membership is for one year. Clients can contact us every day between 9am-9pm via email or phone. We believe purchasing our Medical Assistance Plan is a good option for international people who are covered by Japanese Health Insurance. We provide quality and prompt assistance to help you find proper insurance-covered medical care in Japan.
strTitle: Health Insurance: 1 Year Plan for Peace of Mind
Travel Insurance: 10 Day Plan for Peace of Mind

strIntroduction: Influenced by Zen Buddhism, "Sadō" , or tea ceremony, has been practiced in Japan for over 1000 years as cultural tradition. The ceremony's purpose extends from religious to recreational, but for this experience, you will get to participate in a traditional yet recreational lesson called "tencha". "Tencha" is the process of preparing "Matcha", a type of green tea that is bitter, and if prepared right, leaves a hint of sweetness. The preparation begins from posture, the stirring of the tea, and even to facial expression! Pretty strict, yes, but master all this and you will be rewarded with great tasting tea and a experience as a true artist of tea preparation. Book it now and find out all about the beauty of tea ceremonies in Japan! (Photo by http://www.flickr.com/photos/zachware/2917321813/)
strTitle: Tea Ceremony : A Japanese Beauty

strIntroduction: For this special gathering we'll be hosting our own little rendition of an Amami Island festival as we utilize our taste buds to closely examine a wide selection of 17 varieties of "kokutou shochu", a local shochu made only in the Amami Islands which integrates sweet brown cane sugar into the brewing recipe. It's an all-you-can-drink gathering until the shochu runs out, so we'll be needing a good number of participants – for safety's sake! And as long as we’re "sampling" such a variety, we’ll also be having a little shochu tasting workshop, where you'll have the chance to cultivate your palate for the delicious nuances of one of Japan's most popular local beverages! "What’s a party without music?!", you say? We've got you covered there too, as a pair of local musicians from Kikai Island (one of the Amami Islands!) will be putting on a live "sanshin" performance (similar to the more widely well-known "shamisen"). Come on out and kick back, relax, and absorb the live island tunes and sake for a Saturday afternoon that'll have you feeling like you've been transported to an island far, far away... *Brought to you in cooperation with International TERAKOYA, where the world meets Japan’s fantastic rural cultures and people in the heart of Tokyo!
strTitle: Amami Island Music and Cane Sugar Shochu Event

strIntroduction: Japan is made up of over 6,000 islands, with people inhabiting well over 400 hundred of them. Each of these islands has their own unique and original culture which to this day still goes largely undiscovered by most Japanese. For this particular workshop we'll be focusing on the traditional art of Amami Island, which involves the creation of natural dyes derived from mud and plants which can then be used to dye any number of cloths and patterns. Mentioned in the title of the workshop, "oshima-tsumugi" refers to traditional silks woven and dyed using these carefully crafted dyes, a beautifully refined craft which originated in the Amami Islands. For this special session, you'll have the opportunity take part in a hands-on workshop together with an "oshima-tsumugi" craftsman and a selection of unique dyes shipped up directly from the main island. We're looking forward to having you join us for this unique, one-time-only workshop – a chance to experience Japan's colorful island culture right here in the big city! *Brought to you in cooperation with International TERAKOYA, where the world meets Japan's fantastic rural cultures and people in the heart of Tokyo!
strTitle: Natural Dyes and Oshima-tsumugi Workshop

strIntroduction: "Made in Japan" is the worldwide symbol of top quality. In this tour, you can purchase items such as Japanese TVs, PCs, cameras, audio-visual equipment, watches, and video games at reasonable prices in an area where several electronic shops are centered. I imagine foreign shoppers would face lots of difficulties when trying to shop for electronics. There are so many huge/complicated electronic appliance stores, numerous products with small but important differences, signs written in Japanese and few English-speaking sales clerks...just to name a few possible challenges. In this activity, though, you will be able to enjoy shopping comfortably with an English-speaking ex-sales clerk who has worked at an electronic appliance store. The activity will include: - English-Japanese & Japanese-English Translation - Consultation for your shopping & advice by the ex-salesclerk who is knowledgeable about consumer electronics. You cannot miss this opportunity if you are considering buying top quality consumer electronics. How this activity works... 1. Book this activity. 2. Pre-consultation by e-mail. 3. Meet at Shibuya station. 4. Enjoy shopping!! * The activity cost changes per hour
strTitle: Go Electronics Shopping with a Former Sales Clerk

strIntroduction: Do you like Visual-kei? Visual-kei is a genre of music born in Japan. I'm 20 years old and a college student (junior) majoring in Economics. I love all visual-kei music but especially,” L'Arc-en-Ciel”, “SID”, “the GazettE”, “MUCC”, and “ Alice Nine”. And I’d love to share my passion for Visual-kei music with people from all over the world. So when you come to Japan, let’s have a talk about “visual-kei” music! We can talk about what a typical Japanese university students’ life consists of as well, along with what is hot among young people right now. In this activity, • You can talk with a Japanese Visual-kei fan. • You can get to know a typical Japanese university students’ life. • You can get information about what is hot among young Japanese people. If you are interested in me or visual-kei, let's talk at a cafe! I look forward to meeting you!
strTitle: Have a Talk with a "Visual-kei" University Student

strIntroduction: Want to experience Japanese traditional art, Ikebana? You may think that ikebana is simple a style of flower arrangement but it's much more. Ikebana is an authentic Japanese art through which we enjoy rearranging plants to ultimately appreciate the beauty of simplicity. Not only flowers themselves, we even care about the shape of trunks, leaves and branches. And Ikebana having a long history, there are lots of schools for the art. In this activity, I will teach you the Sogetu school of Ikebana which emphasizes a free style of work. I also am fluent in other schools of flower arrangements, so I can teach you the differences between all of them. Schedule of the activity: 1. What is Ikebana? (brief lecture) 2. Explanation about the basics of Ikebana and the differences between normal flower arrangement and ikebana. 3. Begin to Ikebana! Come and experience Japanese culture through Ikebana!
strTitle: Ikebana: Japanese Flower Arrangement

strIntroduction: Eat a Japanese home meal at a share house! For Japanese people, "Nabe" (hot pot) is a very familiar meal. It’s delicious and it warms both your body and heart. It’s a perfect meal during the cold days of winter. In this activity, you can eat Nabe in our share house "Night Hills" with the tenants and fun members there. You won’t find this style of homemade Nabe in any restaurants. We will decide what type of Nabe we’ll cook that day at your request, such as Chanko-nabe, Kimchi-nabe, soymilk-nabe and giblets-nabe. *Chanko-nabe is Nabe for Sumo Wrestlers (Japanese professional wrestlers) Our share house has a projector screen and hundreds of Japanese books in a large living room. We’re also really close (about a five minute walk) to the famous sightseeing places "Roppongii Hills" and "Tokyo Midtown". So, please add us on your sightseeing plan!
strTitle: Eat Japanese Hot Pot with Merry Companions

strIntroduction: Can you guess what Sweet Decoration is? Sweet Decoration is the act of decorating your belongings! For example, you might decorate your iPhone case or pocket mirror with macaron and whipped cream, strawberry and so on - all made from silicon. To make whipped cream parts, you will squeeze it out from a tube like real whip cream! (Other parts are already made for you) It sounds pretty hard to decorate right? But I assure you - it's not! Even if you're just a beginner or have no experience of decoration as well, don't worry! We will prepare all materials and tools that will be necessary for the decoration. On top of that, you will receive instructions on how to decorate a mirror and make an original macaron key holder - from a teacher who does it professionally for business! Both mirror and key holder will make for a great souvenir! Let's Decorate!
strTitle: Make Your Mirror Look Like Candy!

strIntroduction: Are you interested in a healthy meal with Japanese local food? If so, join this activity! "Macrobiotic" is a diet regimen, that consists primarily of grain and millet dishes that are paired with local and seasonal vegetables. In this activity, you will learn how to cook macrobiotic Japanese food. You'll also see the diverse range of Japanese food here. Through cooking and eating, you will learn what a Japanese macrobiotic diet consists of. One more offer: As I am also a dancer, you can learn dancing with me if you want! Please ask me if you do! I look forward to meeting you!
strTitle: Cook and Taste Macrobiotic Japanese Food

strIntroduction: In this activity you will… Go along with a couple Japanese cosplayers to one of the most festive “cosplay” events in Japan – the “Toshimaen” cosplay event. Normally, this place is home to a giant amusement park and a pool but when the pool is not in service, which is all but during the summertime, the site turns into a stage for the cosplayers. There are plenty of locker rooms and amenities at the site – making it a very popular destination for cosplayers. If you want to “cosplay” yourself, don’t hesitate. There’ll be a bunch of other cosplayers at the event. You will see them as different kinds of anime characters such as NARUTO, BLEACH, Black Battler and Fullmetal Alchemist. If you would rather just watch the cosplayers, you can join this event to take photos and enjoy the atmosphere that makes you feel like you’re in a world of manga. Schedule of the activity: 1. Meet the Japanese Cosplayers 2. Go to Toshimaen together 3. After arriving at Toshimaen, change into "cosplay" clothes or wait for the "cosplayers" to change. 4. Take photos and enjoy "Toshimaen"!
strTitle: Join a Cosplay Event in Toshimaen

strIntroduction: Lolitas are called Lolitas because they all dress up in Lolita fashion – a genre that originated in Japan. The fashion is based on Victorian-era clothing and outfits that appeared during the Rococo period. Although a subgenre, this fashion is fast emerging as a new form of mainstream Japanese culture. A lot of women, regardless of nationality, are being dazzled by the fashions’ cute and frill covered outfits. It's not just the outfits, though, that are important - tea parties are essential to a Lolita. What is a lolita tea party? Tea parties are hosted by Fashion brands, celebrity lolitas, and ordinary lolitas alike. At these parties, they spend time chatting and exchanging information about the most hot topics in lolita fashion. Joining a Japanese lolita tea party is extremely interesting. You will for sure see a rare side of Japan. Whether you are a Lolita or not, this is a great opportunity to connect with Lolitas in Japan as well as its culture. Basic flow of the activity: 1. Meet Japanese lolitas 2. Attend a Tea party and be introduced to the world of Loltia! (2500 yen is an entrance fee and doesn't cover drinks or food. Drinks are around 500 yen each and food around 800 yen)
strTitle: Join a Lolita Tea Party

strIntroduction: Are you interested in the latest Tokyo fashion? Do you know where to get it? We have organized an excellent shopping tour in the hottest fashion spots in Tokyo - Shibuya and Harajuku! An expert of that area will guide you to the towns that are continually developing and generating new fashion trends in Tokyo. A few of the most famous areas of shopping are Shibuya 109, Laforet Harajuku and Takeshita street in Harajuku. You will be an expert of Japanese fashion after taking this tour! Don’t hesitate to tell us any of your requests as well such as the taste of clothes you like or particular fashion items you want. We would love to help you find your favorite stores in Shibuya and Harajuku - those shops that are difficult to find on your own. Don’t miss this chance to experience the hottest fashion culture and festivities of Tokyo.
strTitle: SHIBUYA "Kawaii" Shopping

strIntroduction: Making a basic healthy Japanese bento box for lunch is a creative process in itself, but a kyaraben will definitely make it a bit more fun and even more creative. In a kyaraben, every single side dish and even rice in your bento are designed to look like cute cartoon characters, animals, or even beautiful plants with decorations. Making a kyaraben used to be just a trick to make children eat their lunch, but now it has turned into an art. There are even competitions for making original “kyarabens”. “kyaraben” making has spread throughout Japan but there is still room for making it popular around the world - which we continually aspire to do. In this program you will learn how to make either a Hello Kitty or Pokemon kyaraben. Make sure to choose which kyaraben you would like to make when you book this activity. You will also learn how to make healthy tofu balls, flowers out of cherry tomatoes, and sunflowers out of small sausages. Schedule: 1. Meet up at the Misato chuo Station that is 25 min away from Akihabara st. or 17 min from Asakusa st. and then go to the Kitchen 2. Recipes for the "Kyarabens" will be given to you after a short explanation of them 3. Cook according to the instructions 4. Take pictures of your creations 5. Eat the “kyarabens” you made with your fellow participants.
strTitle: Make Your Own "Kyaraben"

strIntroduction: Using your name, birthdate, astrology, and statistical analysis the fortune teller can counsel you on your future and even tell you secrets about yourself that you didn't know. Ultimately, the fortune teller can provide you with guidance on your future and how to achieve the best possible results in all that you do. - Meet in a casual cafe setting and have your fortune told over tea and coffee. - Ask and receive answers to any and all questions you have regarding your future and things that may be troubling you. - Learn about your future and receive spiritual counseling and advice on how to improve your life from the information learned about what lies ahead.
strTitle: Fortune Telling with original method

strIntroduction: You can discover an entire story packed into a mere 4-frame comic strip, one of the fundamental forms of Japanese manga. At a long-venerated manga cafe, located in the heart of the publishing world, one can witness a part Japan's manga culture firsthand, not just with your eyes, but also with your hands and a trusty pencil. - Learn the history of the 4-frame style and Japanese Manga according to the pros. - Try to make your own dialogue and story from pre-made comics. - Discover the meaning behind the drawings and illustrations with our coordinator's guidance. - Test your creativity and design a 4-frame comic with your own original illustrations and dialogue (We can help if you are not comfortable with illustrations).
strTitle: Manga : Create Your Own 4-Frame Comic Strip

strIntroduction: Rakugo is a form of traditional Japanese comedic stage performance where the lone storyteller portrays and acts out various scenes of the story using only a Japanese folding fan called a sensu, a Japanese hand towel called a tenugui, and their wit. Rakugo contains several established and often told stories, but the performance of these stories is different depending on the storyteller. In this regard, a Rakugo performance and its comedic value extends beyond the story itself to involve the storyteller's delivery, their personality, and their own interpretation of the story. - Choose and learn a popular Rakugo story - Learn how to deliver the story in Rakugo fashion with guidance from the instructor - Become familiar with the props used in Rakugo and how to effectively use them - Stage a Rakugo performance and receive feedback from the instructor.
strTitle: Learn Traditional Japanese Comedic Stage Performance: Rakugo

strIntroduction: We assist the Tohoku Disaster volunteer efforts. Our efforts include ensuring a place to stay as well as securing a means of transportation. As far as volunteer activities, you can choose anything from general cleanup all the way to more labor-intensive work. You can also enjoy your time with the local people, as well as at the hot springs. Your length of stay and how you spend your time are yours to determine. - Our coordinator will pick you up from the volunteer center on the first day and take you to the lodge for orientation on activities that will begin the following day. - In the morning, you will be taken back to the volunteer center. Each morning you will select an activity or task. - Everyone will split off into groups based on their activities. There will be about 5-6 hours of break time each day. - After activities for the day conclude, we will return to the lodge. Free time begins after 5pm. You are responsible for your own initial transportation to the Wataricho volunteer center. For example, here are directions from Tokyo Station: - Tokyo Station(東京駅) → Sendai Station(仙台駅) (2hrs via bullet train) - Sendai Station(仙台駅) → Watari Station(亘理駅) (30min via the Joban Line) - Watari Station(亘理駅) → Wataricho Volunteer Center (approx. 20min by foot) Please send us a message if you have any questions about how to arrive.
strTitle: Aid in the Recovery of the Quake-Striken Tohoku Area

strIntroduction: Indian culture and its textiles are interwoven. There is nothing quite like the insightful embrace of one of India's most respected and valued cultures - textiles. Come on a journey to meet textile craft communities in Gujarat and indulge in a rich, diverse cultural experience, complete with historical context, wrapped with local interactions and cuisine . This journey will be filled with new friendships, fonder appreciation and understanding on Indian textiles, and memories worth a thousand counts. Day 1: On arrival into Ahmedabad, India’s historical cradle otherwise known as the `Tortoise's Back‘ we head straight to check into Diwan’s Bungalow , (time permitting) else head straight for a curated walk around the world-renowned Calico Museum of Textiles archiving textiles from the Mughal and Provincial Courts with a display of intricate dyeing, weaving, printing and embroidery techniques from across India. Late lunch at Swati Snacks, where a quick bite must include panki and sugar cane juice or thaleepeeth, and khichu cooked to spiced perfection! Post this we head to meet Villo Mirza , who has done some pioneering work with craft and textiles for SEWA for many years and now runs her own trust working with women on applique and patchwork based design. We return to our boutique hotel and refresh ourselves before we head to a sit down dinner at Agaashiye , at the charming House of MG, where we enjoy the cool evening breeze and indulge in their special Khansa Thali. A long day draws to an end as we get some much needed shut eye. Day 2: This morning we take a her;itage walk in the old city, including exploring old havelis and rani no hajeero, the quintessential amdavaadi market. Lunch is at the Green house café, followed by a quick stop over at Art Book Centre, to meet Manohar bhai who will wax eloquent about the best books ever written on Indian textiles and sell you some in the bargain offering a deal sweeter than basundi. Straight after this we head to meet the Chitaras, a handful of artists that still make hand painted Pachedis- a kalamkari art form traditional to Gujarat. In olden times, the Harijan community or the lower castes, often labeled untouchables, did not have access to temples. Made on cotton or silk fabric, hand painted Pachedis worked as their own personal shrines that were used for worship of the Goddess. Time permitting a visit to Bandhej to meet Archana Shah author of ‘Shifting Sands’ documenting decades of her work with craftsmen and women of Gujarat. An interaction with her at the store and we leave for the evening at Vishaala. No trip to Ahmedabad is complete without a trip to Vishaala to savour Gujarati hospitality at its best. Bursting at the seams, we come back to Diwan’s and retire for the night. Day 3: Packed breakfast in tow we have a very early start to this day as we drive out of Ahmedabad to Bhuj, the textile centre within the Kutch District in Gujarat, approximately 299km away. Lunch with Jabbar bhai Khatri in Dhamadka followed by a demonstration of Ajrakh, we spend some time at the printing unit and we’re on our way to visit Dr. Ismail Khatri, one of the masters in Ajrakh and a pioneer in the art . Ajrakh literally meant aaj ke din rakh, or 'keep it for today' because that is what the process is. At every stage of the tedious dying process, the fabric should dry for three to four days. Nature plays an important role in the making of Ajrakh. Craftsmen work in total harmony with their environment, where the sun, river, animals, trees and mud are all part of its making. A discussion on the Ajrak textiles at his workshop makes for engaging conversations over a reflective and relaxing cup of tea with the Khatris.. Drive back into Bhuj and before we wind up for the day we meet Ali Mohammed Isha, a textile intellectual who walks us through a tie-dyeing technique knows as Bandhani, a laborious all hand done tie-dye printing process. Tonite we dine at Prince, a traditional meal, and head back to our halt for the night, the Garha Safari Lodge. Its been a long day and we pack in early. Day 4: After exploring the property in the morning, and an early breakfast, we head to to Bhuj to meet an avid textile collector cum expert, and look at some of his collections dating back to the late 1800 and early 1900s, not just in the rabari embroidery styles but also the most exquisite phulkaris and kanthas. Food for the soul truly. Then we head to Bhujodi in the heart of Kutch where we spiral into discussions on traditional pit looms and shuttle looms and hear from Shyamji Vankar, about the challenges faced by the vankars known for their extra weft wool weaving . After our interactions, over lunch with the vankars, we make our way toward an interaction with the Rabari community known for their homes. Here we see the indigenous mud homes decorated by women, with a royal color sensibility and embedded with mirrors for a touch of local glamour. Dinner at a local eatery in Bhuj and we head back to the Lodge and retire for the night. Day 5: We check out of the Garha Safari Lodge and head to Shrujan. We check into their traditional bhungas, and meet the team at Shrujan who expose us to women craftsman working on sustaining the traditional embroidery of the Mochi Bharat (cobbler's stitch) and Rabari techniques unique to Gujarat. Lunch at Shrujan over inspiring interactions with Chandaben or Ami Shroff, the force behind Shrujan. Since it’s inception, Shrujan has supported hundreds of villages and brought the region worldwide recognition for its unimaginably beautiful embroidered textiles.In it’s work, Shrujan highlights 16 different embroidery styles each specific to a different tribe. Post lunch, we’re at Khamir, looking at other crafts that Kutch is also home to - wood, leather, pottery, and metal crafts. Later this afternoon, we watch extraordinary fabrics coming to life as the upholders of the single ikat patola tradition weave silk and cotton threads and then tie and dye them into works of art. Back to Shrujan for the evening, relax and assimilate all that you have seen these last 5 days. Day 6: A visit to Kala Raksha, in Sumarasar, as its name suggests, a grassroots enterprise committed to preserving the traditional arts and craft of Kutch, reveals the most exquisite hand embroidered and patch worked garments and accessories, and a collection of old costumes and embroideries which will take your breath away. A quick lunch at Sankalp and we head straight out to Dasada. Arrive in time for late dinner. Day 7: A 6:00 am morning is fit for a 2 hour safari. Around the Little Rann of Kutch, an Indian Wild Ass Sanctuary rich in biodiversity. After spotting some White- footed Desert Foxes, Striped Hyenas and Golden Jackal, we settle down for breakfast before checking out. A quick stop over at the Sun Temple in Modhera and a visit to Patan’s Step Well, a storage system using steps to reach the water despite high or low water levels, often covered and a curious architectural interest. Lunch enroute at some place, and we drive on to Ahmedabad and straight to the airport for our flights back.
strTitle: Following the Thread - A Textile Trail in Gujarat

strIntroduction: Experience the intensity of the Walled City and unravel its rich history! The Shah Jahan Tour is the classic recipe for an exhilarating glimpse into the life and times of the great Mughal Emperor, Shah Jahan and the 1500 acre expanse of his capital - Shahjahanabad. At the time of its construction in the 17th Century, it was arguably the most prosperous and beautiful city in the world. Today, when you pass through its four hundred year old web of alleys held together with great big meshes of electric cables and infused with the smell of brewing tea and simmering breakfast curry, you see a mind boggling co-existence of the past and the future, competing for your attention. Emerging from this rainforest, thick with traditional architecture- typical of Shah Jahan’s time, you will find yourself in a Delhi of another time while you also see the Red Fort, Jama Masjid, the Spice Market and tranquil Civil Lines, the former British colonial area as a sharp contrast to hectic Old Delhi.
strTitle: Cycle through Old Delhi: The Shah Jahan Tour

strIntroduction: If you want to hike, experience the nature, ancient heritage, tribal art and culture in one place, then Kotagiri is your obvious choice. Kotagiri is a small town in the Nilgiri district of Tamilnadu. It is situated at an altitude of 2200 meters above the sea level, and is only 20 kms from Ooty (Ootacamund) and 75 Kms from Coimbatore. It is the home to tribes such as Kurumbas, Todas, Irulas, Kotas and Paniyas. Kotagiri is a hiker's paradise with endless trails. This area is also very rich in wildlife, the Indian Gaur can be spotted grazing in the wooded areas, and the other animals that thrive here are leopards, spotted deer, and wild boar. This is a 2 days trip with one night stay in a dormitory in a tea estate. Upon the arrival at Coimbatore, participants will be taken on a private vehicle to our campsite in Kotagiri. It is approximately a 2.30 hours drive. After refreshment and breakfast, you will be visiting Banagudi Shola - the sacred grove of the Kurumba tribes in the first day morning. Walk through the banagudi shola and visit the dolmens and the community’s centuries old places of worship. This shola patch is a bird watcher’s paradise where you can see the bird species endemic to Nilgiris biosphere. Post lunch at our campsite walk to the Catherine waterfalls and drench yourself in the cold water. The day ends with campfire and dinner. The second day starts with hot tea and a nature walk to the breathtaking view of kallar valley. After breakfast, you would visit Bikkapathymund – a Toda tribal hamlet. It would take approximately 1.30 hours hike to reach the tribal hamlet. You can talk to the village elders about their traditions and see the women doing embroidery works (for which they are known for). You will be served packed lunch. Post lunch you will trek back to reach the starting point. The trip ends with shopping at the “Green shop” where you could buy fair trade & tribal produces, and you will be dropped at Coimbatore.
strTitle: Trek, Bird Watch, and Experience the Nature of the Nilgiris

strIntroduction: Ladakh is often seen as a last frontier by travellers. Once upon a time it was on the crucial trade route between Central Asia and China. Remnants of those influences can still be seen across Ladakh. Today, the region is politically important having borders with both Pakistan and China. Culturally it is rich with the varied influences coming through. Ladakh is also where the Indus originates – the river that gives India its name. Summer is when the most festivals take places in Ladakh and the visitors pour in to get a glimpse of this unique landscape. Tourism forms an important part of the economy of this harsh land. PAGIR is a group of people with disabilities and their families who are working for improved livelihoods for those like themselves. They wanted to move away from viewing people with disabilities as charitable cases and get into the mainstream economy of tourism. And that is how Himalaya on Wheels emerged. It is a holiday that lets you spend a day with a Ladakhi family if you like. It also has activities for guests with mobility issues. Day 1 – Reach Leh and rest in the hotel to acclimatize to the high altitude. It takes about a day to get used to the lower oxygen at this high altitude. There is no correlation between age, sex, physical fitness and high altitude sickness (HAS). So it is best to relax the first day. If you have any symptoms such as headache, nausea, hallucinations, do speak to our team and they will get you medical help. The doctors in Leh are well trained to handle HAS. Often the solution is as simple as giving oxygen or moving to a lower altitude. Day 2 – We head west towards the Sham Valley. On the way we will stop at the Gurudwara Patthar Sahib, the Indus-Zanskar Confluence and the Alchi Monastery, the oldest in the region. At night, we will stop at the Uley Tokpo resort. Set amongst orchards, it gives you a view of the Indus flowing way below its cliff. Day 3 – you have the choice of trekking upto a nearby village before lunch or heading back to Leh. If the latter, we will stop at the Likir monastery, SECMOL and the Hall of Fame Museum. SECMOL is an NGO working on social issues of the region. They will share with us their work around educational reforms and passive solar heating. The Museum has been set up by the Army and traces the history of the region. You spend the night in Leh. Day 4 – We can start as late as you want as today is spend in and around Leh – Shanti Stupa, Shey Gompa, Choglamsar – monasteries around Leh. Choglamsar is a Tibetan settlement relatively untouched by tourism. The monks here are open to discussions if you are interested. You could also choose to spend the day with a Ladakhi family, helping them with their work and maybe learn to cook their food. This is optional, so please let us know beforehand. Day 5 – Head to Pangong Lake stopping at Sindu Darshan on the way. You will cross the Changla pass, the third highest motorable road in the world. Spend the night by the Pangong Lake. Day 6 – Wake up early to catch the sun rise and just laze around by the Lake. Head back to Leh by around 10.00 am. Meet with your hosts, the PAGIR team, who operate the Himalaya on Wheels itinerary for Travel Another India. PAGIR – People’s Action Group for Inclusion and Rights – are a group of people with disabilities and their families who are working to improve their livelihoods and make Leh cleaner through their waste to craft programme. Himalaya on Wheels was set up by them since they wanted to move away from charity to getting a slice of the main economy of Ladakh which is tourism. You can visit their shop, Junkgwa Shrunkyob, later in the Leh market. Day 7 – Time to leave and send us your beautiful photos and travelogues.
strTitle: Visit the Breathtaking "Plateau of the World": Leh-Ladakh

strIntroduction: Located in Central India's Bundelkhand region, the village guest house is about 3 km from Chanderi, famous for its silks. Visit the village and let the rhythm of the looms create magic for your eyes and ears while you interact with weavers and design your own drape. The more adventurous could try their hand at weaving. Watch village life or visit the historic city of Chanderi while its past is unravelled brick by brick. Enjoy the folk tales hidden in the heart of Bundelkhand and surrender to folk music and lively dances of another India! Amraee will rejuvenate you with its earthiness and historic charm. The Amraee Guest House was set up as part of a UNDP and Government of India project to promote rural tourism. It was formally inaugurated in 2008 and open to guests since September 2011. The Pranpur Village Tourism Development Committee maintains and runs the guest house. Its main aim is to promote the weavers, potters and metal workers while developing the village as a tourist site. You can directly interact with the local craftspeople and buy products from them, ensuring maximum revenue to them and recognition of their skills. The guesthouse itself is set in a 5-acre mango orchard. Amraee derives its name from Aam (mangoes) and Raee (a Bundelkhandi folk dance). The house is built in traditional Bundelkhandi style architecture - all the four rooms are spacious, clean and comfortable with western style bathrooms attached. Experiences • Take a walk around the village and interact with artisans • Try your hand at turning a pot or weaving • Satiate your taste buds with Bundelkhandi thali • See (and join in) the Bundelkhandi folk dance Raee and Sehra • Enjoy a Bullock-cart ride • Visit the fields and participate in farming activities • Go shopping! Within 2 hours • Chanderi (3 km) - A small historic town with many monuments and home to Chanderi fabric • Monuments at Chanderi have been lovingly restored and maintained by the Scindia Foundation • Chanderi Museum (5 km) - A well maintained museum • Rajghat Dam (10 km) - One of the biggest dams in India, lovely place to see sunrise • Nanon (28 km) - A scenic place on the banks of river Urvashi, famous for pre-historic rock paintings • Kadwaya (60 km) - A cluster of temples, also known as mini-Khajuraho • Deogarh (72 km) - Ruins of Jain temples in the middle of a forest by the side of Betwa river
strTitle: Visit a Rural Village & Learn the Art of the Silk Handloom

strIntroduction: One of the most remarkable features of the Khasi hills are the sacred forests, which have been preserved by traditional religious sanction since the ancient days. Trekking in the Abode of Clouds, Meghalaya is an experience will surely rejuvenate your senses like never before. Experience the misty blue hills with unique cultural experiences, great food and stunning campsites. We are proud to offer you this thrilling trip that will take you from rivers to caves, from the midst of broom forest to picturesque valleys. In this trek we take you to explore living root bridges, caves, mountain streams and other hidden treasures of Meghalaya. Come and experience the Khasi hospitality, camping at one of the most remote villages in Meghalaya. === Detailed Itinerary === Day 1 (5-6 Hours) We drive to Khrang, a remote village in the Cherrapunjee road from Guwahati via the picturesque hill station of Shillong. We start trekking from Khrang to Mawshuit and set up our base camp there. Have a cultural night at Mawshuit with traditional Khasi dance followed by an interaction with the locals. Learn about the Khasi way of life in this small but beautiful village set up in midst of green valleys covered with broom plantations and natural flora and fauna.. Overnight stay in tents. Day 2 (6-7 Hours) We start early and trek through the subtropical forest to reach to the magnificient living~root bridge 500 feet above the Wah Muor. Experience the thrill of trekking through thick forest and the old (now abandoned) market trail. Proceed downwards to Wah Muor and enjoy the crystal clear water in the heart of the forest. Proceed further to our next destination the caves. Trek to Krem (cave) Mawlynghoh and experience the thrill of exploring a virgin cave. Trek back to the village through the sub tropical forest crossing beautiful streams and valleys on the Way. Overnight stay in tents. Day 3 (6-7 Hours) After breakfast start trekking for Wah (river) Sohkhain and Wah Muru. Learn the traditional way of fishing and even catch a fish if lucky. Trek back to the village walking along the river. Relax at campsite with bonfire and music. Day 4 (5-6 Hours) Trek back to Khrang and drive back to Guwahati. Trip ends. * Program Schedule and routes are subject to change without prior notice (in unfavourable circumstances). * A11 guests are advised to get their travel insurance done before any adventure trip.
strTitle: Trek through the Sacred Forests of Meghalaya

strIntroduction: Home to the colorful and vibrant Naga tribe, Dzukou valley is branded as one of the most fascinating valleys of Nagaland. Also known as 'The Valley of Flowers', it is situated at an altitude of 2134 meters behind the Japhu ranges in the Eastern Himalayas. Different varieties of flowers from lilies to rhododendrons bloom during the monsoon giving the valley a carpet of flowers.The Dzukou valley offers one of the most captivating spots for bird-watching and trekking in Nagaland round the year. Duration: 5 days Grade: Easy Max elevation: 3014 meters This trek has two itineraries. You can chose between the 5-day itinerary that includes Japhu Peak ( 2nd highest peak in Nagaland) and the 3 day trip that includes Dzukou valley only. Detailed Itinerary: Day 1: Enchanting train ride from Guwahali, crossing rural villages and hills to reach Dimapur town by noon. Drive about 4 hours from Dimapur to the historic Khonoina village via Kohinm. Visit Khonoma fort and nearby villages, interact with locals and experience the Naga way of life. Camp overnight. Day 2: Start trekking and climb steadily for about 4 hours crossing a mountain into Dzukou valley. If lucky, you might spot the colourful Tragopan pheasant, the state bird of Nagaland. Explore the surrounding areas and camp overnight at the Ghost cave, locally know as the bhoot gufa. Day 3: Get up early and drive to Vishwema village and then trek to the base of Japhu peak and camp there overnight. Explore villages and nearby areas and also visit the tallest Rhododendron tree in the world (109 foot) in Japfu range. Day 4: We start early morning and reach Japhu peak after a steep climb to watch the breathtaking sunrise from the top. Witness amazing views of entire Naggaland and surrounding valleys from the peak. After spending some time at the peak we descend through the same route and reach Vishwema and then drive out to the beautiful hill station of Kohima. local sightseeing, in Kohima and overnight stay at hotel. Day 5: We drive to Dimapur and take a train ride back to Guwahati.
strTitle: Trek The Valley of Flowers & Take in the Beauty of Nagaland

strIntroduction: What is a home stay? A home stay is not just bed and breakfast. It is staying with the Indian family. Being a guest of the family... getting a peek into the Indian household. Detailed Tour Itinerary DAY 1: Arrival in Sawantwadi Upon arrival at your home­stay in Sawantwadi, you will be warmly welcomed by your Indian host family with a traditional garland and tikka. Your hosts will then assist you with the registration procedure and show you to your room. Upon settling in you will be taken around the home­stay property and given the opportunity to meet and mingle with your host family. After getting to know one another you will have a delicious lunch together. After lunch you can rest for a while. After your afternoon tea, you can visit the palace and later take a walk in the market. In the evening you will enjoy another home cooked dinner and of course a truly relaxing nights’ sleep. DAY 2: Puppetry & Rangoli Design Workshop Wake up and enjoy the warmth of a home made Indian breakfast prepared caringly by your host family. Today morning you will spend time interacting with the rangoli artists. Rangoli is the art of designing with coloured powder. The artsist will take thru the journey on how the simple designing has undergone change over the period of time. Lunch will be at the home stay. After your meal you will head out to the Pinguli Art Gallery. This art complex aims to showcase, revive and promote a dying folk art tradition by creating a platform for the artist and his community to pursue the age old craft of puppetry and to open avenues for artistic and creative exchange with participants from across the globe. After a touring of the complex you can sit down and view an original puppet show by local artists. After the display, you will head back to your home­stay. In the evening you will be invited to dine with your host family and enjoy another succulent dinner. DAY 3: Dolphin Cruise Today early morning, you will be heading out for an exciting trip of dolphin watching! A boat will take you out into the deep see where you will soon be surrounded by beautiful dolphins. Spend the morning at sea before heading back to your home­stay for a flavourful Indian lunch and siesta. Evening at leisure. DAY 4: Departure from Sawantwadi Today you can sleep in and wake up to have a relaxed breakfast with your host family. After you finish your meal it will be time to pack up your belongings, say your goodbyes to your gracious host family and depart for your onward journey home, surely with many wonderful memories from your trip.
strTitle: Homestay Getaway: Puppet Shows and Dolphin Watching

strIntroduction: A 4 day package giving you a first­hand glimpse into the village life. Understand the pillars of an Indian village ­ the panchayat, the village temple, the village well and the village school. In the village, every community has its rightful place of existence. Join in this package and understand the social weave and its importance. Detailed Tour Itinerary DAY 1: Arrival in Sawantwadi Upon arrival at your home­stay in Sawantwadi, you will be warmly welcomed by your Indian host family with a traditional garland and tikka. Your hosts will then assist you with the registration procedure and show you to your room.
